content: # Open Vent Heating System Fault Finding Guide
This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for open vent heating systems, including feed and expansion tanks, open vent pipes, cold feed issues, and header tank problems.
- **Functions**: System filling, pressure regulation, expansion volume
- **Connections**: Cold feed down, open vent up, overflow, mains supply
- **Location**: Rises from boiler/system to above F&E tank water level
- **Function**: Safety device allowing steam/water escape during overheat
- **Termination**: Must discharge visibly above water level in F&E tank
- **Location**: From base of F&E tank to return side of system
- **Function**: Provides make-up water and creates system pressure
- **Requirements**: 15mm minimum, no valves that could cause isolation
- **Configuration**: Connects at neutral point (typically boiler return or low loss header)
- **Motorized valves**: May separate heating and hot water circuits
- **Pumps**: Circulation for both heating and hot water
- **Cylinder**: Indirect heat exchange for hot water
- **System pressure**: Created by gravitational head from F&E tank
- Static pressure from vertical height (1 bar per 10.2m)
- Expansion accommodated by increasing water level in F&E tank
- Overpressure protection via open vent pipe
- System automatically maintains pressure via float valve
- Visible indication of system problems (overflow, water level)
- Auto air removal via open vent
- Systems with heat-leak radiators for power outages
## PART 2: FEED AND EXPANSION TANK ISSUES
- Frequent need to top up system
- Water level too high or too low
- Check water level (should be 1/3 to 1/2 full when cold)
- Verify correct lid position and insulation
- Look for signs of previous overflow (staining)
- Check for free movement without binding
- Test for correct water level setting
- Verify cold feed and vent pipes correctly positioned
- Check for corrosion at pipe connections
- Ensure no valves on open vent or cold feed
- Confirm overflow is correctly routed outside
- Symptoms: Water from overflow, constantly running float valve
- Cause: Faulty float valve, incorrect water level setting
* Ensure valve seat is clean and undamaged
- Symptoms: System needs frequent topping up, air in radiators
- Cause: System leaks, float valve set too low
- Symptoms: No heat, overflow pipe frozen, tank ice formation
* Properly insulate tank and adjacent pipes
* Confirm loft insulation doesn't block tank heat
* Consider trace heating for extreme situations
* Ensure tank is on insulated base
- Symptoms: Rust-colored water, pitting in tank, leaks
- Cause: Age, poor water quality, no lid
### F&E Tank Location and Installation Issues
- Minimum 450mm above highest point in system
- Must be above all automatic air vents
- Position allows for gravity circulation in power cut
- Inadequate support (should spread load across joists)
- Proximity to cold water storage affecting temperature
- Impact of water leak on ceiling below
- Radiators hot at bottom, cold at top
- Ejection of water from vent pipe
- Trace vent pipe from boiler to F&E tank
- Check for visible blockages or damage
- Look for signs of water discharge or steam marks
- With system cool, pour small amount of water down vent
- Check for free flow into F&E tank
- Verify water level rises in tank
- Check for water backing up in pipe
- Check for pressure relief valve discharge
- Monitor F&E tank water level and behavior
- Look for water discharge from vent pipe
- Symptoms: No flow through pipe, system over-pressurizes
* Physically clean or rod vent pipe
* Consider pipe replacement if severely scaled
* Check F&E tank for debris that could enter pipe
- Symptoms: Restricted flow, gurgling, air locks
- Cause: Incorrectly sized pipe, improper routing
* Correct any dips or horizontal runs
* Ensure continuous rise to F&E tank
* Remove any valves in vent pipe
* Check for crushed or damaged sections
- Symptoms: Slow pressure relief, intermittent noise
* Consider pipe replacement if severely restricted
* Install strainer at system connection point
- Risk of pressure relief valve discharge
- Do not operate system with known blocked vent
- If blockage suspected, shut down system until fixed
- Never cap or valve off an open vent
- Do not attempt to unblock with system hot or under pressure
- Keep clear of vent termination during investigation
- Maintain F&E tank lid to prevent debris entry
- Annual visual inspection of vent pipe
- Trace cold feed from F&E tank to connection point
- Check for visible restrictions or damage
- Verify no valves installed in cold feed line
- Look for signs of improper installation
- Check for external damage or freezing
- Drain small amount of system water
- Observe refill rate from F&E tank
- Check for air being drawn into system
- Time recovery of system water level
- Monitor system behavior during heating cycle
- Verify if pressure drop coincides with pump operation
- Test if air enters system during cool-down
- Listen for pump cavitation during operation
- Symptoms: Very slow refilling, pressure issues
* Isolate and clean cold feed pipe
* Consider pipe replacement if severely scaled
* Install strainer at F&E tank outlet
- Symptoms: Air ingress, slow refill, pressure fluctuations
* Check for proper connection at system
* Ensure no high points causing air locks
- Symptoms: Air being drawn into system, pump noise
* Verify connection at neutral point in system
* Check connection orientation (avoid top of pipe)
* Ensure connection not near pump intake
* Modify connection to prevent air entrainment
- Must handle maximum potential flow rate
- At neutral point (typically before boiler return)
- Continuous fall from F&E tank where possible
- Install removable test point for flow verification
## PART 5: HEADER TANK FLOAT VALVE FAILURES
- Test for prompt opening when lowered
- Listen for water passing when valve closed
- Check float for water ingress (sink test)
- Examine arm for bending or damage
- Inspect valve seat for debris or damage
- Verify correct adjustment and water level
- Check for pressure drop during operation
- Confirm suitable valve type for pressure
- Symptoms: Water constantly flowing to overflow
- Cause: Debris on valve seat, damaged washer
* Ensure adequate clearance from tank sides
- Symptoms: Low water level, system air problems
* Adjust float arm for correct level
* Verify valve size adequate for system
* Consider upgrading to larger capacity valve
- Symptoms: Water level fluctuations, intermittent overflow
* Install pressure reducer if supply pressure fluctuates
* Consider equilibrium valve for problematic installations
- Symptoms: Tank overflows, float sits low in water
* Ensure proper arm attachment to float
- Quiet action models for noise-sensitive locations
- Ensure adequate clearance from tank sides
- Install isolating valve before float valve
- Use PTFE tape or appropriate jointing compound
- Verify correct arm adjustment after installation
- Test operation through full range of movement
- Replace older Portsmouth valves with modern diaphragm type
- Consider pressure-reducing valve for high pressure supplies
- Install anti-splash tube for noisy installations
- Consider servicing kit if valve body in good condition
- Hot water rises, cold water falls
- Dependent on correct pipe sizing and routing
- Typically used for cylinder heating or heat leak radiators
- No restrictions or valves that impede flow
- Verify cylinder heats during boiler operation
- Ensure heat leak radiator warms during firing
- Check for convection current using temperature probe
- Verify no crossflow with pumped circuits
- Check for restrictions or partial blockages
- Symptoms: Heat travelling in unintended direction
- Cause: Competing flow paths, poor design
- Symptoms: Gravity circuit inactive when pump running
* Add check valve to prevent reverse flow
* Consider dedicated gravity circuit from boiler
- Insulate pipes to maintain temperature differential
- Create thermal store effect in cylinder
- Secondary circulation pump with power outage override
- Heat leak port in primary system
- Modern pre-plumbed cylinders with backup circulation
## PART 7: REFERENCE TABLES AND TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDES
| Component | Height Above Highest Radiator | Static Pressure | System Application |
| F&E Tank | 0.5m | 0.05 bar | Minimum working height |
| F&E Tank | 1.0m | 0.1 bar | Typical domestic installation |
| F&E Tank | 3.0m | 0.3 bar | Recommended for larger systems |
| F&E Tank | 10.0m | 1.0 bar | Maximum practical height |
| System Type | Cold Feed Minimum | Open Vent Minimum | Gravity Circuit Minimum | Notes |
| Solid Fuel | 28mm | 28mm | 35mm | Must not be able to be isolated |
| System Capacity | Minimum Tank Volume | Expansion Allowance | Recommended Size |
*Note: Expansion allowance should be minimum 4% of system volume*
### Common Open Vent System Faults and Solutions
| Boiler noises | Kettling, bubbling | Blocked vent pipe | Clear blockage, check pipe size |
| System air | Needs frequent bleeding | Low water level, feed issue | Check F&E tank, cold feed |
| Overflow running | Water from overflow pipe | Float valve fault | Replace washer, adjust float |
| No heat after power cut | Cold radiators | Poor gravity circulation | Check pipe size, routing |
| Frozen F&E tank | No heating, burst risk | Inadequate insulation | Insulate tank, pipes, add lid |
| Pump cavitation | Noisy pump operation | Restricted cold feed | Clean/replace cold feed pipe |
| Poor heating | Slow to heat, cold spots | Flow restrictions | Check for blockages, clean system |
